description: From Middle English sparke, sperke, from Old English spearca, from Proto-Germanic *sprakô (compare Dutch spark and sprank, Middle Low German sparke), from Proto-Indo-European *sperg- (“to strew, sprinkle”) (compare Breton erc’h (“snow”), Latin spargō (“to scatter, spread”), sparsus (“scattered”), Lithuanian sprógti (“to germinate”), Ancient Greek σπαργάω (spargáō, “to swell”), Avestan 𐬟𐬭𐬀𐬯𐬞𐬀𐬭𐬈𐬔𐬀‎ (frasparega, “branch, twig”), Sanskrit पर्जन्य (parjanya, “rain, rain god”)).

entries.meaning: A small particle of glowing matter, either molten or on fire.
A short or small burst of electrical discharge.
A small, shining body, or transient light; a sparkle.
(figuratively) A small amount of something, such as an idea or romantic affection, that has the potential to become something greater, just as a spark can start a fire.
examples: But though we have, here and there, a little of this clear light, some sparks of bright knowledge

entries.meaning: Any of various lycaenid butterflies of the Indomalayan genus Sinthusa.
(in plural sparks but treated as a singular) A ship's radio operator.

examples: At the other extreme, with limitless budgets all they have to do is dream up amazing lighting rigs to be constructed and operated by the huge team of gaffers and sparks, with their generators, discharge lights, flags, gobos and brutes.

verbs.description: spark (third-person singular simple present sparks, present participle sparking, simple past and past participle sparked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To trigger, kindle into activity (an argument, etc).

examples: Byron sparked the cigarette. He sucked it dramatically and thrust it into Marko's hand.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a gun) To shoot; to fire
(intransitive) To give off a spark or sparks.

description: Probably Scandinavian, akin to Old Norse sparkr (“sprightly”).

entries.meaning: A gallant; a foppish young man.
examples: The finest sparks and cleanest beaux.

verbs.description: spark (third-person singular simple present sparks, present participle sparking, simple past and past participle sparked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To woo, court; to act the gallant or beau.
